elements.content: One-dimensional (1D) electronic systems have attracted significant attention for a long time because of their various physical properties. Among 1D electronic systems, 1D halogen-bridged mixed-valence transition-metal complexes (the so-called MX chains) have been thoroughly studied owing to designable structures and electronic states. Here, we report the syntheses, structures, and electronic properties of three kinds of novel neutral MX-chain complexes. The crystal structures consist of 1D chains of Pt–X repeating units with (1R,2R)-(−)-diaminocychlohexane and CN– in-plane ligands. Because of the absence of a counteranion, the neutral MX chains have short interchain distances, so that strong interchain electronic interaction is expected. Resonance Raman spectra and diffuse-reflectance UV–vis spectra indicate that their electronic states are mixed-valence states (charge-density-wave state: Pt2+···X–Pt4+–X···Pt2+···X–Pt4+–X···). In addition, the relationship between the intervalence charge-transfer (IVCT) band gap and the degree of distortion of the 1D chain shows that the neutral MX chains have a larger IVCT band gap than that of cationic MX-chain complexes. These results provide new insight into the physical and electronic properties of 1D chain compounds.

Among 1D electronic systems, 1D halogen-bridged mixed-valence transition-metal complexes (the so-called MX chains) have been thoroughly studied owing to designable structures and electronic states. Here, we report the syntheses, structures, and electronic properties of three kinds of novel neutral MX-chain complexes. The crystal structures consist of 1D chains of Pt-X repeating units with (1R,2R)-(-)-diaminocychlohexane and CN- in-plane ligands. Because of the absence of a counteranion, the neutral MX chains have short interchain distances, so that strong interchain electronic interaction is expected. Resonance Raman spectra and diffuse-reflectance UV-vis spectra indicate that their electronic states are mixed-valence states (charge-density-wave state: Pt2+⋅⋅⋅X-Pt4+-X⋅⋅⋅Pt2+⋅⋅⋅X-Pt4+-X⋅⋅⋅). In addition, the relationship between the intervalence charge-transfer (IVCT) band gap and the degree of distortion of the 1D chain shows that the neutral MX chains have a larger IVCT band gap than that of cationic MX-chain complexes. These results provide new insight into the physical and electronic properties of 1D chain compounds.

elements.content: Low-dimensional electronic systems have attracted significant attention in the field of fundamental science because various physical parameters, such as electron–lattice interaction (S), on-site (U) and intersite (V) Coulomb repulsions, and transfer integrals (t), are competing with one another. In particular, one-dimensional (1D) electronic systems have been intensively studied by chemists and physicists because of their various physical properties, such as high conductivity, large optical nonlinearity, solitons, polarons, and Tomonaga–Luttinger liquid behavior.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Low-dimensional electronic systems have attracted significant attention in the field of fundamental science because various physical parameters, such as electron-lattice interaction (S), on-site (U) and intersite (V) Coulomb repulsions, and transfer integrals (t), are competing with one another. In particular, one-dimensional (1D) electronic systems have been intensively studied by chemists and physicists because of their various physical properties, such as high conductivity, large optical nonlinearity, solitons, polarons, and Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid behavior.

elements.content: Among 1D electronic systems, 1D halogen-bridged mixed-valence transition-metal complexes (the so-called MX chains) have been thoroughly studied as ideal examples of 1D electronic systems owing to designable structures and electronic states. They show a variety of interesting properties, including third-order nonlinear-optical susceptibility, luminescence with a large Stokes shift, strong 1D antiferromagnetic interaction, and long-range migration of spin solitons and polarons along the 1D chain. MX chains have an infinite 1D chain structure composed of metal (M) and bridging halide (X) ions (a), and their 1D electronic systems consist of d z 2 orbitals of metal ions and p z orbitals of bridging halide ions. In general, the electronic ground state of MX-chain systems can be classified into two types depending strongly on the central metal species. For platinum and palladium complexes, the electronic state in the MX chain corresponds to a charge-density-wave (CDW: M2+···X–M4+–X···M2+···X–M4+–X···; b) state because of strong electron–lattice interaction (S). For nickel complexes, the electronic state corresponds to the Mott–Hubbard (MH: M3+–X–M3+–X–M3+–X–M3+–X–; c) state because of strong electron correlation (U). The MX-chain system has advantages over other 1D materials, such as organic polymers and semiconducting nanowires, because its electronic states can be widely and finely tuned by changing its components, such as the bridging halide, ligand, and counterion. To date, more than 300 kinds of MX-chain compounds have been reported.

In general, the electronic ground state of MX-chain systems can be classified into two types depending strongly on the central metal species. For platinum and palladium complexes, the electronic state in the MX chain corresponds to a charge-density-wave (CDW: M2+⋅⋅⋅X-M4+-X⋅⋅⋅M2+⋅⋅⋅X-M4+-X⋅⋅⋅; b) state because of strong electron-lattice interaction (S). For nickel complexes, the electronic state corresponds to the Mott-Hubbard (MH: M3+-X-M3+-X-M3+-X-M3+-X-; c) state because of strong electron correlation (U). elements.content: Recently, in search of novel electronic states, we have been developing extended MX systems such as two-legged MX-ladder and four-legged MX-tube systems. These materials are composed of two or four MX chains that are linked to one another by organic rung ligands to form ladder or tubelike structures. In these systems, interchain electronic interaction through the organic rung ligand offers unique electronic properties, which are quite different from those of a single MX-chain system. For example, pairs of in-phase and out-of-phase CDW states within the ladder are realized in some two-legged MX-ladder compounds (). In addition, the relationship between the intervalence charge-transfer (IVCT) band gap and the degree of distortion of the MX chain shows a tendency different from that of other MX-chain complexes. In the case of the four-legged MX-tube complex, a variety of CDW states are expected to be realized. These results indicate that interchain electronic interaction plays an important role in the realization of unique electronic states.

In addition, the relationship between the intervalence charge-transfer (IVCT) band gap and the degree of distortion of the MX chain shows a tendency different from that of other MX-chain complexes. In the case of the four-legged MX-tube complex, a variety of CDW states are expected to be realized. These results indicate that interchain electronic interaction plays an important role in the realization of unique electronic states.

elements.content: In this work, we focus our attention on neutral MX-chain systems. In general, MX-chain complexes have a cationic 1D chain structure, which is counterbalanced by the presence of counteranions (a), resulting in long interchain distances. On the other hand, in neutral MX-chain complexes, the absence of counteranions provides short interchain distances (b), which would introduce relatively strong interchain electronic interactions compared with those of cationic MX chains. There are only a limited number of neutral MX-chain platinum complexes, including Pt­(NH3)2X3 (X = Cl, Br, I), Pt­(en)­X3 (en = ethylenediamine), Pt­(NH3)2(SCN)2I, Pt­(en)­(SCN)2X (X = Br, I), and Pt­(dach)­X3 [dach = (1R,2R)-(−)-diaminocychlohexane; X = Cl, Br]. They were reported more than 20 years ago, and to the best of our knowledge, only three of them [Pt­(NH3)2Br3, Pt­(en)­Br3, and Pt­(en)­I3] were crystallographically identified. In addition, the relationship of their structure and electronic state has not been discussed in detail.

They were reported more than 20 years ago, and to the best of our knowledge, only three of them [Pt(NH3)2Br3, Pt(en)Br3, and Pt(en)I3] were crystallographically identified. In addition, the relationship of their structure and electronic state has not been discussed in detail.

elements.content: Here, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and electronic states of three kinds of novel neutral MX-chain complexes, Pt­(dach)­X­(CN)2 [X = Cl (5), Br (6), I (7)]. The existence of anionic in-plane ligands (CN–) leads to a neutral MX-chain structure with short interchain distances. In addition, we demonstrate that the neutral MX-chain system shows a distinct correlation between lattice distortion and the IVCT band gap compared with those of the cationic MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems.
elements.clean_text: Here, we report the syntheses, crystal structures, and electronic states of three kinds of novel neutral MX-chain complexes, Pt(dach)X(CN)2 [X = Cl (5), Br (6), I (7)]. The existence of anionic in-plane ligands (CN-) leads to a neutral MX-chain structure with short interchain distances. In addition, we demonstrate that the neutral MX-chain system shows a distinct correlation between lattice distortion and the IVCT band gap compared with those of the cationic MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems.

Reagents and solvents were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., TCI Co., Ltd., and Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The starting material, Pt­(dach)­Cl2, was synthesized according to a published procedure. Pt­(dach)­Cl2 (490 mg, 1.3 mmol) and AgCN (388 mg, 2.9 mmol) were added to 30 mL of water and stirred at 353 K for 8 h. The mixture was filtered while hot, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness. A white crystalline powder was obtained (yield: 427 mg, 83%). Needle-shaped colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography of 1 were obtained by slow cooling and evaporation of the hot filtrate. Elem anal. elements.content:
Elemental analyses for all compounds were performed using Yanaco MT-5 and MT-6 CHN recorders at the Center for Elementary Analysis, Kyoto University.

Single-Crystal X-ray Crystallography

X-ray crystal structure analyses of 1 and 3–7 were carried out using a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD detector with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 100 K. The single crystals were mounted on a glass capillary with grease. The structures were solved by direct methods (SIR2004 and SIR2008), expanded using Fourier techniques (DIRDIF99), and refined by full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2 (SHELXL-2013 and SHELXL, version 2014/3) using the CrystalStructure software package. Refinement results for 1 and 3–7 are summarized in and the Supporting Information. Crystallographic data in CIF format have been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre (CCDC) under deposition numbers CCDC 1443940–1443945. These data can be obtained free of charge via www.ccdc.cam.ac.uk/data_request/cif (or from the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K.). Synchrotron X-ray crystal structure analyses of 5–7 at 50 K were also performed using a CCD detector with cold-helium gas flow installed in the BL02B1 beamline of SPring-8 (λ = 0.6996 Å). Because of heavy sample degradation by radiation damage, full structural analyses of 6 and 7 using synchrotron radiation were not successful.

X-ray oscillation photographs of 5–7 were collected using a Bruker SMART APEX II CCD detector with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) with ω scan mode (0.3° steps).

Diffuse-Reflectance Spectroscopy

Diffuse-reflectance spectra on 5–7 diluted in CaF2 powder were recorded using a JASCO model ISN-470 60 mm ϕ integrating-sphere apparatus. The obtained reflectance spectra were converted to absorption spectra according to the Kubelka–Munk function F(R ∞).

elements.content: The divalent platinum complex 1·2H2O was synthesized from the reaction of Pt­(dach)­Cl2 and AgCN in water. Halogen oxidation of 1 offered tetravalent platinum complexes Pt­(dach)­X2(CN)2 [X = Cl (2), Br (3), I (4)]. Single crystals were obtained for 1, 3, and 4 (Figures S1a–c), and their crystal structures were determined using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD; see the Supporting Information). The molecular structures of 1, 3, and 4 are shown in . Although single crystals of 2 could not be obtained, the IR spectra of 2–4 clearly show that 2 has a molecular structure similar to those of 3 and 4 (Figure S2).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and X-ray Crystal Structures

The divalent platinum complex 1⋅2H2O was synthesized from the reaction of Pt(dach)Cl2 and AgCN in water. Halogen oxidation of 1 offered tetravalent platinum complexes Pt(dach)X2(CN)2 [X = Cl (2), Br (3), I (4)]. Single crystals were obtained for 1, 3, and 4 (Figures S1a-c), and their crystal structures were determined using single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD; see the Supporting Information). The molecular structures of 1, 3, and 4 are shown in . Although single crystals of 2 could not be obtained, the IR spectra of 2-4 clearly show that 2 has a molecular structure similar to those of 3 and 4 (Figure S2).

elements.content: Novel neutral MX-chain compounds Pt­(dach)­X­(CN)2 [X = Cl (5), Br (6), I (7)] were synthesized from the equimolar reactions of 1 and 2, 3, or 4 in methanol. Single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography of 5–7 were obtained by slow evaporation of the methanol solution (Figures S1c–e). The crystallographic data for 5–7 are summarized in . Compounds 5–7 crystallize in the space group P21212 and are isostructural with one another. The crystal structures are shown in . Overall, their structures consist of a symmetrically equivalent platinum unit, [Pt­(dach)­(CN)2] used as the precursor, and propagate along the a axis through bridging halide X [X = Cl (2), Br (3), I (4)] (a–c). The bridging halide ions are disordered with half-occupancies between two sites around the midpoints of adjacent platinum ions, as is often observed in other MX-chain systems. These results indicate that their electronic states correspond to the mixed-valence state (CDW: Pt2+···X–Pt4+–X···Pt2+···X–Pt4+–X···). The nearest Pt–Pt, Pt2+···X (Pt1···X1*), and Pt4+–X (Pt1–X1) distances within one MX chain are 5.425, 3.104, and 2.325 Å for 5 (X = Cl), 5.565, 3.081, and 2.494 Å for 6 (X = Br), and 5.765, 3.073, and 2.711 Å for 7 (X = I), respectively (). Parts d and e of show perspective views of three-dimensional (3D) packing in the ab and bc planes of 5. The nearest interchain distances (along the b axis) are 5.035 Å for 5, 4.979 Å for 6, and 4.986 Å for 7, which are much smaller than those of the usual cationic MX-chain compounds (>6.8 Å). Because of the absence of counteranions, interchain electronic interactions among chains are expected to be induced. The selected bond lengths and angles around platinum ions for all complexes are summarized in Table S1. However, no significant difference among them is observed. Besides, the Pt–N distances for 5–7 (2.077–2.099 Å) are comparable to those of the cationic MX-chain complexes without CN– in-plane ligands (e.g., 2.069 Å for [Pt­(dach)2Cl]­Cl2 and 2.083 Å for [Pt­(dach)2I]­I2), although the cyanide ligand is well-known to have a very strong ligand field. shows typical X-ray oscillation photographs of 5–7 at 100 K, which reflect information about the electronic states of MX chains. The observation of spot-type reflections indicates 3D long-range order within the crystals. In the case of 5–7, spot-type reflections were observed at h + 1/2 kl (white short arrows in ), which correspond to the 2-fold periodicity along the MX-chain direction. This suggests the existence of 3D long-range ordering of CDW states within the crystal. In other words, this means that the interchain interaction is strong in 5–7, as we expected. However, the SCXRD analyses including these reflections were not successful because the intensities of these superlattice reflections were not strong enough. SCXRD analyses using synchrotron radiation at 50 K were also not successful.

To investigate the electronic states of 5–7, Raman and diffuse-reflectance spectra were measured. shows Raman spectra of 5–7 at room temperature. The intense peaks of symmetrical stretching modes ν­(Pt–X) (X = Cl, Br, I) with overtone progressions were clearly observed at 314 (5), 184 (6), and 130 (7) cm–1, respectively. In the diffuse-reflectance spectra (), intense and broad peaks were observed at about 3.0 (5), 2.4 (6), and 1.5 (7) eV, which were attributable to the IVCT transition from Pt2+ to adjacent Pt4+ sites. With a change in the bridging halide, the IVCT band gaps increased in the order of I < Br < Cl, which is explained by the degree of the overlap integral between the p z orbital of the halide and the d z 2 orbital of the metal. These results are strong evidence of the CDW state (Pt2+···X–Pt4+–X···), which is in good agreement with the SCXRD results.
elements.clean_text:
Electronic Properties

To investigate the electronic states of 5-7, Raman and diffuse-reflectance spectra were measured.  shows Raman spectra of 5-7 at room temperature. The intense peaks of symmetrical stretching modes ν(Pt-X) (X = Cl, Br, I) with overtone progressions were clearly observed at 314 (5), 184 (6), and 130 (7) cm-1, respectively. In the diffuse-reflectance spectra (), intense and broad peaks were observed at about 3.0 (5), 2.4 (6), and 1.5 (7) eV, which were attributable to the IVCT transition from Pt2+ to adjacent Pt4+ sites. With a change in the bridging halide, the IVCT band gaps increased in the order of I < Br < Cl, which is explained by the degree of the overlap integral between the p z  orbital of the halide and the d z  2 orbital of the metal. These results are strong evidence of the CDW state (Pt2+⋅⋅⋅X-Pt4+-X⋅⋅⋅), which is in good agreement with the SCXRD results.

elements.content: In the MX-chain system, the degree of distortion of the 1D chain is a good parameter for the electronic state, where the distortion is derived from deviation of a bridging halide ion from the midpoint between the Pt2+ and Pt4+ sites. a shows the correlation between the Pt–Pt distance (L 0) and the Pt–X distances [Pt2+···X (l 1) or Pt4+–X (l 2)] for several MX-chain complexes, two-legged MX-ladder complexes, and Pt­(dach)­X­(CN)2 (5–7). In cationic MX-chain systems, it is well-known that there is a linear correlation between the L 0 distance and l 1 and l 2 distances depending strongly on bridging halide species (black circles for Cl–, black triangles for Br–, and black squares for I– in a). In general, shorter L 0 leads to longer l 1 and shorter l 2 because of the larger orbital overlap between Pt 5d z 2 and X p z . As is clearly seen, two-legged MX-ladder compounds and neutral MX-chain complexes (5–7) fall on the same lines as the MX-chain compounds. b displays the correlation between the distortion parameter d, defined as d = (l 1 – l 2)/L 0, and the IVCT energy (E CT). Linear relationships between d and E CT can be seen for both MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems; however, their tendencies are independent of each other, in contrast to the results in a. Compared with the slope of the MX-chain system, that of the two-legged MX-ladder system becomes larger, which can be explained by using inter-rung Coulomb interaction (V rung) or diagonal Coulomb interaction within the ladder ( and S3). According to the extended Peierls–Hubbard model, E CT of an MX chain is represented by E CT = 8 S − U + 3 V where S, U, and V are the electron–lattice interaction and on-site and intersite Coulomb repulsions along the MX chain, respectively (). In the case of the two-legged MX-ladder, the E CT value of the MX ladder with an out-of-phase CDW state (Figure S3) is given by E CT = 8 S − U + 3 V + 2 V rung
elements.clean_text:
Correlation between the Lattice Distortion and Electronic States

In the MX-chain system, the degree of distortion of the 1D chain is a good parameter for the electronic state, where the distortion is derived from deviation of a bridging halide ion from the midpoint between the Pt2+ and Pt4+ sites. a shows the correlation between the Pt-Pt distance (L 0) and the Pt-X distances [Pt2+⋅⋅⋅X (l 1) or Pt4+-X (l 2)] for several MX-chain complexes, two-legged MX-ladder complexes, and Pt(dach)X(CN)2 (5-7). In cationic MX-chain systems, it is well-known that there is a linear correlation between the L 0 distance and l 1 and l 2 distances depending strongly on bridging halide species (black circles for Cl-, black triangles for Br-, and black squares for I- in a). In general, shorter L 0 leads to longer l 1 and shorter l 2 because of the larger orbital overlap between Pt 5d z  2 and X p z . As is clearly seen, two-legged MX-ladder compounds and neutral MX-chain complexes (5-7) fall on the same lines as the MX-chain compounds. b displays the correlation between the distortion parameter d, defined as d = (l 1 - l 2)/L 0, and the IVCT energy (E CT). Linear relationships between d and E CT can be seen for both MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems; however, their tendencies are independent of each other, in contrast to the results in a. Compared with the slope of the MX-chain system, that of the two-legged MX-ladder system becomes larger, which can be explained by using inter-rung Coulomb interaction (V rung) or diagonal Coulomb interaction within the ladder ( and S3). In the case of the two-legged MX-ladder, the E CT value of the MX ladder with an out-of-phase CDW state (Figure S3) is given by 2      E   CT   = 8 S - U + 3 V + 2   V   rung

Data shown for (a1) [Pt(en)2I](l-Asp-C10)2⋅H2O, (a2) [Pt(dach)2I]I2, (a3) [Pt(en)2I](ClO4)2, (a4) [Pt(NH3)4I](HSO3)3(OH), (b1) [Pt(dach)2Br]Br2, (b2) [Pt(etn)2Br]Br2, (b3) [Pt(en)2Br](ClO4)2, (b4) [Pt(dach)2Br](ClO4)2, (c1) [Pt(dach)2Cl]Cl2, (c2) [Pt(tn)2Cl](BF4)2, (c3) [Pt(NH3)4Cl](HSO3)4, (c4) [Pt(dach)2Cl](ClO4)2, (α) Pt(en)Br3, (A) [{Pt(en)I}2(bpym)]I4⋅4H2O, (B) [{Pt(dien)Br}2(bpy)]Br4⋅2H2O, (C) [{Pt(en)Br}2(bpym)]Br4⋅4H2O, (D) [{Pt(en)Br}2(bpym)]Br(ClO4)3⋅H2O, (E) [{Pt(dien)Br}2(dach)](NO3)4, (F) [{Pt(en)Cl}2(bpym)]Cl(ClO4)3⋅H2O, and (G) [{Pt(dien)Br}2(azpy)](ClO4)4⋅C3H6O. ,,

elements.content: Schematics of the IVCT excitation in the usual cationic MX-chain system. Orange, green, blue, and brown spheres represent Pt4+, Pt2+, Pt3+, and bridging halide ions, respectively.
elements.clean_text: 10  Schematics of the IVCT excitation in the usual cationic MX-chain system. Orange, green, blue, and brown spheres represent Pt4+, Pt2+, Pt3+, and bridging halide ions, respectively.

elements.content:
This result indicates that the MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems possess different electronic states.

In the case of the present neutral MX-chain complexes (5–7), as is clearly observed in b, they also show a tendency different from those of the cationic MX-chain and MX-ladder systems. The slope of the line is similar to that of the cationic MX-chain systems but shifted slightly upward. Although the correlation between d and E CT has not been reported so far in neutral MX-chain systems, the previously reported material, Pt­(en)­Br3, clearly obeys this tendency (α in b). For 5–7, this unique tendency cannot be explained by interchain Coulomb repulsion between the nearest neighbors (V inter) because the total of V inter does not change before and after charge-transfer excitation (Figure S4). However, the tendency toward increased E CT compared with the cationic MX chains can be explained by considering the interchain Coulomb repulsion between the second-nearest neighbors (V inter‑2 or V diag‑2; Figure S5). Although the second-nearest interchain distances are 9.96–10.1 Å for 5–7, unscreened long-range Coulomb interaction might provide negligible interchain interactions for their charge-transfer excitations. In the case of cationic MX chains, because of long interchain distances (nearest interchain distances of >6.8 Å) and the existence of a layer of counteranions between adjacent MX chains, these interchain Coulomb interactions would be screened and not be effective (a). On the other hand, for the present neutral MX chains (b), the short interchain distance and absence of counteranions would provide relatively strong interchain interaction, resulting in larger E CT.

elements.content: In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized three kinds of novel neutral MX-chain compounds. Single-crystal X-ray studies showed that they have small interchain distances owing to the absence of counteranions between adjacent MX chains. We first examined the correlation of the IVCT band gap and the distortion parameter d and demonstrated that the neutral MX-chain system has distinct electronic states compared with the MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems. The results presented here offer valuable insight into the realization of unique electronic states in 1D electronic systems.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, we have successfully synthesized three kinds of novel neutral MX-chain compounds. Single-crystal X-ray studies showed that they have small interchain distances owing to the absence of counteranions between adjacent MX chains. We first examined the correlation of the IVCT band gap and the distortion parameter d and demonstrated that the neutral MX-chain system has distinct electronic states compared with the MX-chain and two-legged MX-ladder systems. The results presented here offer valuable insight into the realization of unique electronic states in 1D electronic systems.

Reagents and solvents were purchased from Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd., TCI Co., Ltd., and Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. and used without further purification.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>1</bold>)

The starting material, Pt­(dach)­Cl2, was synthesized according to a published procedure. Pt­(dach)­Cl2 (490 mg, 1.3 mmol) and AgCN (388 mg, 2.9 mmol) were added to 30 mL of water and stirred at 353 K for 8 h. The mixture was filtered while hot, and the filtrate was evaporated to dryness. A white crystalline powder was obtained (yield: 427 mg, 83%). Needle-shaped colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography of 1 were obtained by slow cooling and evaporation of the hot filtrate. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4Pt·2H2O: C, 24.18; H, 4.57; N, 14.10. Found: C, 23.90; H, 4.66; N, 14.08.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­Cl<sub>2</sub>(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A methanol solution (6 mL) of 1·2H2O (78 mg, 0.20 mmol) was treated with excess Cl2 and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The solution was evaporated to dryness to remove excess Cl2. The obtained black powder was dissolved in methanol. After filtering to remove the insoluble materials, the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for 2 weeks. A pale-yellow powder of 2 was obtained (yield: 126 mg, 90%). Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4Cl2Pt·2H2O: C, 20.52; H, 3.87; N, 11.97. Found: C, 20.85; H, 3.87; N, 11.50.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­Br<sub>2</sub>(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>3</bold>)

A methanol solution containing Br2 (0.2 mM, 4 mL, 0.8 mmol) was added to a methanol solution (6 mL) of 1·2H2O (100 mg, 0.25 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The solution was evaporated to dryness to remove excess Br2. The obtained yellow powder was dissolved in ethanol. After filtering to remove the insoluble materials, the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for 2 weeks. Block-shaped red crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography of 3 were obtained (yield: 78 mg, 83%). Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4Br2Pt·2H2O: C, 17.25; H, 3.26; N, 10.06. Found: C, 17.21; H, 3.09; N, 9.80.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­I<sub>2</sub>(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>4</bold>)

A methanol solution containing I2 (73 mg, 0.33 mmol) was added to a methanol solution (6 mL) of 1·2H2O (100 mg, 0.25 mmol) and stirred at room temperature for 10 min. The solution was evaporated to dryness to remove excess I2. The obtained black powder was dissolved in methanol. After filtering to remove the insoluble materials, the filtrate was allowed to stand at room temperature for 2 weeks. Block-shaped black crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography of 4 were obtained (yield: 138 mg, 84%). Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4I2Pt·2H2O: C, 14.76; H, 2.79; N, 8.60. Found: C, 14.78; H, 2.56; N, 8.48.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­Cl­(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>5</bold>)

1 (30 mg, 0.076 mmol) and 2 (35 mg, 0.076 mmol) were dissolved in methanol. Slow evaporation of the solution afforded needle-shaped yellow single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography in more than 90% yield. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4ClPt: C, 23.17; H, 3.88; N, 13.51. Found: C, 23.10; H, 3.68; N, 13.47.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­Br­(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>6</bold>)

1 (30 mg, 0.076 mmol) and 3 (42 mg, 0.076 mmol) were dissolved in methanol. Slow evaporation of the solution afforded needle-shaped yellow single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography in more than 90% yield. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4BrPt·0.5H2O: C, 21.34; H, 3.36; N, 12.45. Found: C, 21.27; H, 3.14; N, 12.43.

Synthesis of Pt­(dach)­I­(CN)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>7</bold>)

1 (30 mg, 0.076 mmol) and 4 (49 mg, 0.076 mmol) were dissolved in methanol. Slow evaporation of the solution afforded needle-shaped yellow single crystals suitable for X-ray crystallography in more than 90% yield. Elem anal. Calcd for C8H14N4IPt: C, 19.68; H, 2.89; N, 11.48. Found: C, 19.47; H, 2.92; N, 11.37.
